user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of answer_unique_tiny_response:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
answer_unique_tiny_response (void *cls,
                             struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                             const char *url,
                             const char *method,
                             const char *version,
                             const char *upload_data,
                             size_t *upload_data_size,
                             void **req_cls)
{
  static int marker = 0;
  struct MHD_Response *r;
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  (void) cls;  /* Unused */
  (void) url; (void) version; /* Unused */
  (void) upload_data; (void) upload_data_size; /* Unused */

  if (NULL == *req_cls)
  {
    /* The fist call */
    *req_cls = (void *) ▮
    /* Do not send reply yet. No error. */
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */

#if MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (tiny_body),
                                              tiny_body);
#else  /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (tiny_body),
                                       (void *) tiny_body,
                                       MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT);
#endif /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection, MHD_HTTP_OK, r);
  MHD_destroy_response (r);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
#if MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (tiny_body),
                                              tiny_body);
#else  /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (tiny_body),
                                       (void *) tiny_body,
                                       MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT);
#endif /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
explanation: There are no explicit calls to answer_unique_tiny_response within this function, so no direct self-call is present. Most remaining lines are simple parameter casts, local declarations, or strcmp checks (e.g. the method checks) which are standard library calls that do not invoke user callbacks and thus do not introduce indirect recursion. The only places that may result in the server library re-entering this request handler (indirect recursion) are: the initial/early-return handshake that sets *req_cls and returns MHD_YES (the framework may call the handler again later), and calls into the microhttpd API that queue/create/destroy responses. Those API calls are listed above as suspicious fragments and should be investigated to determine whether they can cause the library to call this handler (directly or indirectly). All other code fragments (parameter (void) casts, enum/variable declarations, strcmp-based method checks, return MHD_NO for unsupported method, and the final return ret) do not perform callbacks and therefore do not need further investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2.
